questions.text: A struggling model in Mumbai with normal lungs and an arterial Pco2 of 40 mm Hg takes an overdose of barbiturates that halves his alveolar ventilation but does not change his CO2 output. If his respiratory exchange ratio is 0.8, what will be his arterial Po2 in mm Hg?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

50 mm Hg

If the alveolar ventilation is halved the Pco2 will double. 

PAO2 = PIO2 – (PACO2/RQ)

PIO2 = (PB – PH2O) X fractional concentration of O2

       = (760 – 47) X 21/100 = 150 mm Hg

PAO2 = PIO2 – (PACO2/RQ)

        = 150 – (80/0.8) = 150 – 100 = 50 mm Hg

questions.text: In the steady state, which of the following is the same in ICF and ECF?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Osmolality

The osmolality of the ICF and ECF is the same. In a healthy adult, the ICF volume is twice as large as the ECF volume. The absolute number of osmoles will, therefore, be higher in the ICF.

choices.text: Increased levels of ADH and increased V2 receptor activity
Increased levels of ADH and normal V2 receptor activity
Increased levels of ADH and decreased V2 receptor activity
Decreased levels of ADH and increased V2 receptor activity

questions.text: The patient appears dehydrated, and the plasma osmolality is 320 mOsm/kg. During a water deprivation test there was little increase in urine osmolarity after 6 hours. Desmopressin injection had little effect. Plasma and kidney tissue analysis would be expected to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased levels of ADH and decreased V2 receptor activity

Diabetes insipidus is characterized by excretion of large volumes of extremely dilute urine. It can be “neurogenic” or “nephrogenic”. In neurogenic DI, there is a decreased production of ADH. “Nephrogenic” indicates the problem is the renal response to ADH, not the production of ADH. Plasma ADH levels are usually high, reflecting the ADH releasing stimulus, high plasma osmolality.

If the 24-hour urine collection shows a dilute urine, the diagnosis is confirmed with the water deprivation test. A normal individual should increase the urine osmolarity when water is withheld. The absence of an increase in urine osmolarity indicates impairment in water reabsorption. Injection of desmopressin should result in an increase in urine osmolarity if the kidneys are able to respond to ADH and is used to distinguish central diabetes insipidus from nephrogenic diabetes.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man arrived by ambulance at the emergency department after an industrial accident that cut the femoral artery, causing the loss of 1.5 L of blood. Bleeding was controlled by direct pressure, and the patient received 2 L of 0.9% saline during transport. The patient is pale, diaphoretic, and anxious. Vital signs: BP 80/60 mm Hg, P 120/min and weak, R 22/min and shallow, T 35.5°C. 

Which of the following changes in this patient is contributing to the narrowed arterial pulse pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Decreased; increased; increased

The patient is in hemorrhagic shock. 

Loss of blood produces a fall in blood pressure. Arterial blood pressure is sensed by the arterial baroreceptors. A drop in arterial blood pressure unloads the baroreceptors and causes a sympathetic activation and a parasympathetic inhibition. Sympathetic activation causes increases in heart rate, ventricular contractility, and total peripheral resistance and a decrease in venous capacitance. Sympathetic nerve activation causes the observed increases in heart rate, respiratory rate, and anxiety. In addition, sympathetic nerves to the skin cause vasoconstriction of the blood vessels, accounting for the loss of skin colour. Sympathetic cholinergic nerves activate sweat glands, causing diaphoresis. The common description of a patient in shock is “pale and sweaty.” Arterioles of the cerebral and coronary circulations respond more strongly to local control than to sympathetic activity. Consequently, blood flow to the brain and heart are not diminished by increases in sympathetic nerve activity.

choices.text: Increase in slow wave frequency, increase in contraction frequency
Decrease in slow wave frequency, decrease in contraction frequency
No change in slow wave frequency, decrease in contraction frequency
Decrease in slow wave frequency, no change in contraction frequency

questions.text: A physiology experiment is conducted on an isolated segment of rabbit small intestine being maintained under laboratory conditions at 37 degrees Celsius. The segment of intestine is bathed in a solution with all essential nutrients, ions, and gases. The proximal jejunum is observed to contract at a frequency of 5 contractions/ minute. A glass micropipette is inserted into the interstitial cell of Cajal at the same location in the jejunum, and a slow wave frequency of 10 per minute is recorded. Nor-epinephrine is then added to the solution. What will happen to the slow-wave frequency and contraction frequency after addition of Nor-epinephrine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

No change in slow wave frequency, decrease in contraction frequency

Slow waves are variations in membrane potential, from -65 to -45mV, due to oscillations in the activity of the sodium- potassium ATPase pumps. The slow waves are not responsible for contraction. The frequency of slow waves is not affected by nor-epinephrine or Ach. 

Spike potentials superimposed on the slow waves are responsible for contraction. Nor epinephrine will decrease the frequency of spike potentials and therefore, the contraction frequency.

questions.text: An athlete training for a marathon is suspected to have received illegal erythropoietin injections to increase his red blood cell count. If true, which of the following hemodynamic parameters is expected to be decreased?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Polycythemia increases blood viscosity, which will reduce capillary blood flow by increasing resistance.

questions.text: The graph given below depicts filterability of dextran through the kidney, 1 representing complete filtration and 0 representing no filtration. Which of the following are A, B and C respectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Polyanionic, neutral, polycationic.

questions.text: Formation of CSF by the choroid plexus includes (1) osmosis of water, (2) active transport of sodium, (3) passive diffusion of chloride. Which of the following is the correct sequence of events that occur in the formation of CSF?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

2, 3, 1

Formation of CSF involves an active transport of sodium followed by a passive diffusion of chloride and water. 

The rate of CSF formation is 550mL/day or 0.38mL/min.

choices.text: Absence of atrial and ventricular contractions
Decreased frequency of atrial and ventricular contractions
Increased frequency of atrial and ventricular contractions

questions.text: A patient is given a drug that shortens the duration of phase 4 of the slow-response action potential in the sinoatrial (SA) nodal conduction cells. Which of the following changes to the resultant cardiac contractions would most likely be produced from this drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The duration of Phase 4 of the slow-response action potential determines the frequency of contractions (heart rate). If the duration of phase 4 is shortened, then it takes less time to reach the depolarization threshold, and the frequency of cardiac (atrial and ventricular) contractions increases per minute, and vice versa. A shorter phase 4 of the slow response action potential will increase the number of atrial and ventricular contractions per minute, not decrease or block them

questions.text:
If 

1. First heart sound

2. “a” wave 

3. Rapid ejection

4. T wave

Which of the following is the correct sequence in the cardiac cycle after P wave of ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

2, 1, 3, 4

Atrial depolarization or P wave of ECG is followed by atrial contraction or the “a” wave of JVP. “a” wave of JVP coincides with the second rapid filling phase towards the end of ventricular diastole. First heart sound marks the end of diastole and the beginning of systole. First phase of systole is isovolumetric contraction phase followed by the rapid and slow ejection phases. 

An easy way to remember the sequence of events in the cardiac cycle is :

P a Q R 1 c x T 2 v 3 y

choices.text: Decrease in strength of cardiac contraction

questions.text: A healthy 35-year-old woman stands up from the supine position. Moving from supine to standing position results in a transient decrease in arterial pressure that is detected by arterial baroreceptors located in the aortic arch and carotid sinuses. Which set of cardiovascular changes is most likely to occur in response to activation of the baroreceptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

On standing, effect of gravity causes increased peripheral pooling of blood. There is decrease in venous return, cardiac output and blood pressure. The baroreceptor reflex causes an increase in sympathetic discharge and a decrease in parasympathetic discharge. These result in increase in heart rate, increase in force of contraction of the heart, vasoconstriction and venoconstriction. Venoconstriction also decreases venous compliance, increasing the venous return.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has a mass in the sella turcica that compresses the portal vessels, disrupting pituitary access to hypothalamic secretions. The secretion rate of which hormone would most likely increase in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Prolactin

Prolactin secretion is inhibited by hypothalamic PIF. All others are stimulated by hypothalamic hormones.  Obstruction of blood flow through the hypothalamic- hypophyseal portal vessels would lead to reduced secretion of ACTH, TSH, GH, FSH, LH, but increased secretion of Prolactin.

choices.text: It produces its effect by activating cAMP
It produces its effect by increasing the distal tubular permeability to sodium
It causes an increased secretion of hydrogen ions
It is secreted in response to decrease in blood pressure

questions.text: A/E the following characterize the production and actions of aldosterone in the body-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aldosterone binds to an intracytoplasmic receptor that causes an increased synthesis of proteins, including the Na+- K+ ATPase pumps, ENaCs, K+ channels, which together increase the sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion by the tubular cells of the distal nephron. Aldosterone also increases the H+ secretion in the distal nephron. Aldosterone secretion is stimulated by a decrease in blood volume (through the renin- angiotensin system) and by an increased plasma K+ concentration.

questions.text: The transport of H+ ions into the proximal tubule is primarily associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reabsorption of bicarbonate

In the PCT, for every H+ ion secreted, one bicarbonate is reabsorbed (indirect reabsorption of bicarbonate).

choices.text: Increase in ventricular end diastolic pressure

questions.text: A 80-year-old woman presents with fatigue, edema, and shortness of breath. Her physician prescribes a diuretic and a positive inotropic agent. Which of the following changes is responsible for the improvement in her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Decrease in heart size 

In cardiac failure, the inability to pump blood effectively leads to an increase in EDV and end diastolic pressure, which can lead to pulmonary edema, hence the term congestive cardiac failure. The increased EDV increases the wall stress that must be developed with each beat, and this increases the myocardial oxygen demand. Administration of an inotropic agent increases the stroke volume, which in turn increases the cardiac output. The greater ejection fraction lowers the EDV, which decreases the heart size (radius) and thus wall stress (wall tension), according to La Place law. As a result, myocardial oxygen demand is lowered.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is found comatose in her kitchen by her husband and is brought to the Emergency of a nearby hospital. Blood gas analysis reveals normal Po2 and a lower-than-normal arterial O2 saturation. Which of the following conditions is most consistent with the findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CO poisoning

A normal Po2 and lower-than-normal So2 is indicative of anemic hypoxia. CO poisoning causes anemic hypoxia.

questions.text: A patient reports that he is always thirsty, and his breath has an acetone smell. A diagnosis of diabetes mellitus is confirmed by a urine sample that tests positive for glucose and a blood sample that shows a fasting glucose concentration of 400 mg/dL. Compared with normal, which of the following set of changes will be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

In a patient with uncontrolled diabetes causes a metabolic acidosis. This leads to decrease in urinary pH, increased renal production of ammonium and HCO3-. The glucose in urine causes an osmotic diuresis increasing the urine volume.

questions.text: Which of the following graphs best describes the relationship between Pco2 and alveolar ventilation (VA), when the Pco2 is changed acutely over a range of 35 to 75 mm Hg?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The relationship between increasing Pco2 and its effect on alveolar ventilation is linear. More the Pco2 more will be the alveolar ventilation. The increase in VA can be almost 8 times when the arterial CO2 tension is increased over a physiological range from 35 to 75 mm Hg.

choices.text: Percent O2 saturation in the arterial blood

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of excessive bleeding during her periods and increasing fatigue and cold extremities. Laboratory investigations reveal a Hb of 6gm/dL. In this patient with anemia, which of the following would be increased?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Oxygen extraction 

Oxygen content = (Hb in gm/dL X 1.34 X %saturation) + (Po2 in mm Hg X 0.003mL/dL/mm Hg)

If there is a decrease in Hb, the arterial O2 content of the blood will also be reduced. Oxygen extraction by the tissues increases to compensate for the reduced oxygen delivery to the tissues. Arterial O2, dissolved oxygen and the percentage saturation of hemoglobin with oxygen are all normal in anemia.

questions.text: Which of the following reflexes is correctly paired with its receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Autogenic inhibition- Golgi tendon organ

Receptors for the stretch reflex (also k/a myotactic reflex or deep tendon jerk) are the muscle spindles. 

Reciprocal inhibition is also mediated by the muscle spindles. 

Receptors for the inverse stretch reflex (also k/a autogenic inhibition) are the Golgi tendon organs. 

Nociceptor stimulation is responsible for the flexor withdrawal and the crossed extensor responses.

questions.text: Two alveoli of different sizes are connected to a common airway. If the surface tension is the same in both alveoli, the pressure produced by the surface tension will be higher in which alveolus, and in which direction will air flow between the two alveoli?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The relationship between pressure in the alveolus and surface tension is demonstrated by Laplace’s law:
Tension = (Pressure × Radius)/2. If this equation is written to solve for pressure, Pressure = (2 × Tension)/
Radius), then it is evident that the alveolus with the smaller radius (alveolus 1) will have the higher pressure. That pressure gradient will drive air from the smaller alveolus to the larger alveolus.

questions.text: An increase in the shear stress in a blood vessel is likely to cause which of the following changes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increased NO production

An increase in shear stress in blood vessels is one of the main stimuli for the release of NO by endothelial cells. NO increases blood flow by increasing cGMP.

questions.text: If a person has been exercising for one hour which of the following will have the smallest decrease in blood flow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Brain

After exercising for 1 hour, the blood flow to the GI tract, kidneys, pancreas, non-exercising muscles decreases significantly but the blood flow to the brain remains close to its control value.

choices.text: Decreased secretion of urea by the distal tubules
Increased synthesis of urea by the liver
Increased reabsorption of urea in the PCT

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a h/o renal insufficiency is admitted to the hospital after taking a large amount of ibuprofen. His BUN is 150 mg/dL. The patient’s high BUN was most likely caused by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Decreased GFR 

Urea is synthesized primarily in the liver. It is freely filtered by the kidney. About 50% to 60% of the filtered urea is reabsorbed in the PCT. In renal insufficiency, the GFR decreases resulting in decreased filtration of urea and therefore, decreased excretion of urea. The decreased urea excretion results in an increase in plasma concentration of urea.

questions.text: A 80-year-old patient with a past h/o cirrhosis undergoes a total colectomy. Removal of the entire colon would be expected to cause which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Increase in blood ammonia

One of the action of colonic bacteria is to convert ammonia to ammonium ion. Thus, the total colectomy will increase the blood ammonia levels, which would be exacerbated in a patient with cirrhosis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male has a murmur that ceases with the onset of the second heart sound. Second heart sound occurs at the onset of which phase of the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Isovolumetric relaxation

Second heart sound marks the end of systole and beginning of diastole. The first phase of diastole is the isovolumetric relaxation phase.

questions.text: A patient presents with tachycardia and heat intolerance. The physician suspects Grave’s disease. Which of the following is not consistent with the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Decreased thyroid radioactive uptake 

In Grave’s disease, antibodies against the TSH receptors in the thyroid gland stimulate many steps in the synthesis of thyroid hormones, including increased iodine uptake. Due to excessive stimulation, the thyroid gland hypertrophies and secretes increased amounts of thyroid hormones. The antibodies present in Grave’s disease also cause pathological changes in the tissues surrounding the yes, leading to protrusion of the eyeballs.

questions.text: If the extracellular concentration of calcium is 100mmol/L and intracellular concentration is 1 millimole/ L and 2.3RT/F = 60mV, what is the equilibrium potential of calcium (cell membrane is freely permeable to calcium)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

+60 mV

The equilibrium potential for calcium will be 60/2  log 100/1 = 60 X 2/2 = 60 mV. Calcium will move from outside to inside generating a positive potential inside. The equilibrium potential for calcium will, therefore, be +60mV.

questions.text: A 17-year-old yoga enthusiast lifts her right leg over her head while in the sitting position. Activation of a single pyramidal cell in the motor cortex leads to stimulation of 2000 muscle fibres in her right quadriceps muscle. Which of the following best describes the type neuronal circuitry activated in this woman when she lifts her leg?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Diverging 

A diverging pathway amplifies nerve signals; a single pyramidal cell activating 2000 muscle fibres (single pyramidal cell can activate up to 10000 muscle fibres) is an example of diverging neuronal circuit.  In a converging circuit, multiple input fibres converge on a single post synaptic neuron, which allows summation of information from multiple sources. 

An inhibitory circuit has inhibitory inter neurons that stop the spread of a nerve signal. Reverberatory circuits have positive feedback elements that allow a nerve impulse to continue for a prolonged time.

questions.text: Both the peripheral and central chemoreceptors mediate increased ventilation in response to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hypercapnia

Both the peripheral and central chemoreceptors respond to an increase in Paco2 levels. The peripheral chemoreceptors also cause an increase in ventilation in response to a decrease in arterial pH and a decrease in Pao2. The central chemoreceptors are unresponsive to hypoxemia or to a decrease in arterial pH.

questions.text: The crossed extensor response is initiated by stimulation delivered to which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cutaneous free nerve ending

The crossed extensor response is a polysynaptic, spinal reflex. It is initiated by the stimulation of cutaneous free nerve endings for pain.

choices.text: Increased water permeability of the collecting duct

questions.text: Which of the following will be found in a dehydrated individual deprived of water for 24 hours?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Increased water permeability of the collecting duct

In a dehydrated person, plasma osmolality will increase. Increase in plasma osmolality stimulates the secretion of ADH. ADH increases insertion of aquaporin 2 in the luminal membrane of the collecting duct cells, increasing the water permeability.

questions.text: At which point on the nerve action potential shown in the figure given below is the membrane closest to the equilibrium potential for sodium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Point A

When a stimulus is given to a nerve it causes opening of voltage gated sodium channels which increases the membrane permeability for sodium. Sodium entry into the cell causes the cell to depolarize. The potential reaches +30mV (point A), which is closest to the equilibrium potential for sodium (+60mV).

choices.text: Blood pressure and heart rate increase
Blood pressure and heart rate decrease
Blood pressure increases and heart rate decreases
Blood pressure decreases and heart rate increases

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has a fall from his cycle and sustains a skull fracture which compresses the underlying brain tissue. Which of the following will occur in response to an increased intracranial pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Blood pressure increases and heart rate decreases

Increase in intracranial pressure decreases cerebral blood flow producing CNS ischemia. This in turn increase sympathetic discharge increasing the blood pressure. Increased blood pressure stimulates the baroreceptors producing a reflex bradycardia.

questions.text: The airway pressure of a normal 77-year-old man is approximately 1 cm H2O during expiration. What is his airway pressure during inspiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

-1 cm H2O Expansion of the chest cavity during inspiration causes the airway pressure (also k/a intrapulmonary pressure or alveolar pressure) to become sub-atmospheric, averaging about -1 cm H2O during quiet inspiration, resulting in movement of air into the lungs.

questions.text: Which of the following motor pathways innervate the A gamma motor neurons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reticulospinal tract

Reticulospinal tracts- pontine/ excitatory and medullary/ inhibitory tracts innervate the A gamma motor neurons especially to the lower limb extensors, thereby, controlling extensor muscle tone.

questions.text: A normal 20-year-old male breathes in as much air as he can and then exhales as much air as possible. The lung volume at maximum inspiration is 6.0L, and the lung volume after maximum expiration is 1.0L. His tidal volume at rest is 0.5L, and his functional residual capacity is 3.5L. What is his vital capacity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

5.0L

Forced vital capacity or vital capacity is the volume of air expired forcefully after a forceful inspiration. FVC = TLC – RV = 6.0 – 1.0 = 5.0L.

questions.text: The following diagram shows the changes in hypothalamic set point and body temperature during fever. Which of the following changes will be seen at point B as compared to point A?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sweating

At A, posterior hypothalamus or the heat gain centre causes peripheral vasoconstriction, piloerection, non-shivering thermogenesis and shivering. This results in heat to be generated increasing the body temperature.

questions.text: A large dose of insulin is administered to a patient. Which of the following hormonal changes are NOT likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Increase in aldosterone

Injection of Insulin leads to decrease in blood glucose. Hypoglycemia stimulates the secretion of GH, glucagon and epinephrine, all of which have counter- regulatory effects to increase the glucose levels in the blood. Hypoglycemia does not increase the aldosterone levels.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of essential hypertension is being treated with an ACE-inhibitor. All of the following changes will be expected in this patient except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increase in total peripheral resistance

Angiotensin II is a powerful vasoconstrictor and sodium retaining hormone that increases blood pressure. Administration of an ACE inhibitor decreases Angiotensin II formation. Loss of negative feedback of angiotensin II on renin increases renin secretion. Decreased angiotensin II enhances renal sodium excretion, decreases total peripheral resistance and arterial pressure.

questions.text: Which condition at the S-A node will cause the heart rate to decrease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Increased potassium permeability
 
Increases in sodium and calcium permeability at the S-A node result in an increase in heart rate. An increased potassium permeability causes a hyperpolarization of the S-A node, which causes the heart rate to decrease.

questions.text: Listed below are the hydrostatic and oncotic pressures within a microcirculatory bed. Plasma colloid osmotic pressure = 25 mm Hg Capillary hydrostatic pressure = 25 mm Hg Venous hydrostatic pressure = 5 mm Hg Arterial pressure = 80 mm Hg Interstitial fluid hydrostatic pressure = −5 mm Hg Interstitial colloid osmotic pressure = 10 mm Hg Capillary filtration rate = 150 ml/min What is the capillary filtration coefficient (in ml/min/mm Hg) for this capillary wall?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

10 

The capillary filtration coefficient is calculated as rate of net fluid movement across a capillary wall divided by net filtration pressure. Net filtration pressure = capillary hydrostatic pressure − plasma colloid osmotic pressure + interstitial colloid osmotic pressure − interstitial hydrostatic pressure. The rate of net fluid movement across the capillary wall is 150 ml/min. Capillary filtration coefficient (Kf ) = Filtration rate/Net filtration pressure Kf = 150 ml/min / [Pc − Πc + Πi − PI ] Kf = 150 ml/min / [25 − 25 + 10 − (−5)] Kf = 150 /15 = 10 ml/min/mm Hg.

questions.text: In control conditions, flow through a blood vessel is 100 ml/min under a pressure gradient of 50 mm Hg. What would be the approximate flow through the vessel after increasing the vessel diameter to four times normal, assuming that the pressure gradient was maintained at 50 mm Hg?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

25,600 ml/min

According to Poiseuille’s law, flow through a vessel increases in proportion to the fourth power of the radius. A 4-fold increase in vessel diameter (or radius) would increase 4 to the fourth power, or 256 times normal. Thus, flow through the vessel after increasing the vessel 4 times normal would increase from 100 to 25,600 ml/min.

questions.text: A healthy 22-year-old female medical student has an exercise stress test at a local health club. An increase in which of the following is most likely to occur in this woman’s skeletal muscles during exercise?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

During exercise, tissue levels of carbon dioxide and lactic acid increase. These metabolites dilate blood vessels, decrease arteriolar resistance, and enhance vascular conductance and blood flow.

questions.text: If creatinine clearance = 100 ml/min, urine flow rate = 1.0 ml/min, plasma Na+ concentration = 140 mmol/l, and urine Na+ concentration = 80 mmol/l, what is the approximate rate of Na+ excretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Urine excretion rate of Na+ is equal to urine flow rate (1.0 ml/min or 0.001 l/min) multiplied by urine Na+ concentration (80 mmol/l), or 0.08 mmol/min.

questions.text: If a person maintains a high (150 mmol/day) potassium diet, which part of the nephron would be expected to reabsorb the most potassium? Choose the appropriate nephron site in the figure below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Approximately 65% of the filtered load of potassium is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. Variations in renal excretion of potassium during change in potassium intake are achieved mainly by changes in potassium secretion in collecting tubules. With high potassium intake, the proximal tubule still reabsorbs a high fraction of the filtered load of potassium.

choices.text: Hypertonic, compared with plasma, in antidiuresis

questions.text: In normal kidneys, which of the following is true of the osmolarity of renal tubular fluid that flows through the early distal tubule in the region of the macula densa?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

As water flows up the ascending limb of the loop of Henle, solutes are reabsorbed, but this segment is relatively impermeable to water; progressive dilution of the tubular fluid occurs so that the osmolarity decreases to approximately 100 mOsm/l by the time the fluid reaches the early distal tubule. Even during maximal antidiuresis, this portion of the renal tubule is relatively impermeable to water and is therefore called the diluting segment of the renal tubule.

questions.text: Donnan effect is seen on distribution of -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Due to the presence of non-diffusible ion one side of the membrane, the distribution of other ions to which membrane is permeable (diffusible ion) is affected in a predictable way.

questions.text: One gram of mannitol was injected into a woman. After equilibration, a plasma sample had a mannitol concentration of 0.08 g/L. During the equilibration period, 20% of the injected mannitol was excreted in the urine. The subject’s-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mannitol is a marker substance for the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume. ECF volume = amount of mannitol/concentration of mannitol = 1 g – 0.2 g/0.08 g/L = 10 L.

questions.text: A selective decrease in efferent arteriolar resistance would __________ glomerular hydrostatic pressure, __________ GFR, and __________ renal blood flow.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Decreased efferent arteriolar resistance would increase renal blood flow while reducing glomerular hydrostatic pressure, which, in turn, would tend to decrease the GFR.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman runs a 10-km race on a hot day and becomes dehydrated. Assuming that her ADH levels are very high and that her kidneys are functioning normally, in which part of the renal tubule is the most water reabsorbed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

In normally functioning kidneys, approximately two thirds of the water filtered by the glomerular capillaries is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. Although dehydration increases ADH levels and water reabsorption by the distal tubules, collecting tubules, and collecting ducts and this action contributes importantly to decreased water excretion in dehydration, the total amount of water that remains in these tubular segments is small compared with the amount of water in the proximal tubules.

choices.text: Glucose reabsorption cannot be estimated from these data

questions.text: If a person has a kidney transport maximum for glucose of 350 mg/min, a GFR of 100 ml/min, a plasma glucose level of 150 mg/dl, a urine flow rate of 2 ml/min, and no detectable glucose in the urine, what would be the approximate rate of glucose reabsorption, assuming normal kidneys?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

In this example, the filtered load of glucose is equal to GFR (100 ml/min) × plasma glucose (150 mg/dl), or 150 mg/min. If there is no detectable glucose in the urine, the reabsorption rate is equal to the filtered load of glucose, or 150 mg/min.

questions.text: A scientist is designing experiments to better appreciate how the lung expands. He acquires two sets of cat lungs and fills one set with saline. He plots changes in the lungs' volume with respect to pressure as shown in Image A. The pressure-volume loop of the liquid-ventilated lung is different from the gas-ventilated lung because of what property?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This question assesses your familiarity of the pressure-volume curve in respiratory physiology. The liquid-ventilated lung has increased compliance compared to the gas-ventilated lung, thus producing a steep curve as shown in the figure. In normal respiration, lung volume is always less during inhalation than exhalation at any given pressure. This phenomenon is called hysteresis. During inspiration of air, the collapsing force of surface tension must be overcome. Lungs produce surfactant to minimize surface tension. Thus, pressure increases immediately on inspiration, but volume does not increase until surface tension is overcome. During expiration, volume decreases with pressure increase because no active force is needed to maintain patent airways. With saline, surface tension is further minimized because the air-fluid boundary is removed. Thus, compliance increases and the inspiratory and expiratory curves look similar.

questions.text:
Which curve describes the inulin profile along the nephron?

The curves show the percentage of the filtered load remaining in the tubular fluid at various sites along the specimen.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Once inulin is filtered, it is neither reabsorbed nor secreted. Thus,100% of the filtered inulin remains in tubular fluid at each nephron site and in the final urine.

questions.text:
Which curve describes the alanine profile along the nephron?

The curves show the percentage of the filtered load remaining in the tubular fluid at various sites along the specimen.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Alanine, like glucose, is avidly reabsorbed in the early proximal tubule by a Na+–amino acid cotransporter. Thus, the percentage of the filtered load of alanine remaining in the tubular fluid declines rapidly along the proximal tubule as alanine is reabsorbed into the blood.

Partial occlusion of a blood vessel increases the Reynolds number (and turbulence) because the decrease in cross - sectional area results in increased blood velocity (v = Q/A).

questions.text: Following a sympathectomy, a 66-year old man experiences orthostatic hypotension. The explanation for this occurrence is-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Orthostatic hypotension is a decrease in arterial pressure that occurs when a person moves from a supine to a standing position. A person with a normal baroreceptor mechanism responds to a decrease in arterial pressure through the vasomotor center by increasing sympathetic outflow and decreasing parasympathetic outflow. The sympathetic component helps to restore blood pressure by increasing heart rate, contractility, total peripheral resistance (TPR), and mean systemic pressure. In a patient who has undergone a sympathectomy, the sympathetic component of the baroreceptor mechanism is absent.

questions.text: Curve A in the figure represents
questions.solution:

Aortic pressure increases steeply after QRS, as blood is ejected from the ventricles. After reaching peak pressure, aortic pressure decreases as blood runs off into the arteries. The characteristic dicrotic notch (“blip” in the aortic pressure curve) appears when the aortic valve closes. Aortic pressure continues to decrease as blood flows out of the aorta.

questions.text: A hospitalized patient has an ejection fraction of 0.4, a heart rate of 100 beats/min, and a cardiac output of 3.6 L/min. What is the patient’s end-diastolic volume?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation- First, calculate stroke volume from the cardiac output and heart rate: Cardiac output =stroke volume X heart rate; thus, stroke volume= cardiac output/heart rate 3600 mL/100 beats/min = 36 mL. Then, calculate end-diastolic volume from stroke volume and ejection fraction: Ejection fraction = stroke volume/end-diastolic volume; thus end-diastolic volume = stroke volume/ejection fraction= 36.8 mL/0.4 = 90 mL.

questions.text: A healthy 10-year-old boy breathes quietly under resting conditions. His tidal volume is 400 ml, and his ventilation frequency is 12/min. Which of the following best describes the ventilation of the upper, middle, and lower lung zones in this boy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The lower zones of the lung ventilate better than the upper zones, and the middle zones have intermediate ventilation. These differences in regional ventilation can be explained by regional differences in pleural pressure. The pleural pressure is typically about −10 cm H2O in the upper regions and about −2.5 cm H2O in the lower regions. A less negative pleural pressure in the lower regions of the chest cavity causes less expansion of the lower zones of the lung during resting conditions. Therefore, the bottom of the lung is relatively compressed during rest but expands better during inspiration compared with the apex.

questions.text: Which of the following would be expected to increase after surgical removal of the duodenum?

Removal of the duodenum would remove the source of the gastrointestinal (GI) hormones, cholecystokinin (CCK), and secretin. Because CCK stimulates contraction of the gallbladder (and, therefore, ejection of bile acids into the intestine), lipid absorption would be impaired. CCK also inhibits gastric emptying, so removing the duodenum should accelerate gastric emptying (or decrease gastric emptying time).

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with Crohn's disease diagnosed in her early 20s comes to your office for a follow-up appointment. She is complaining of headaches and fatigue. Which of the following arterial blood findings might you expect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This patient presents with Crohn's disease, which can cause anemia of chronic disease. Patients with anemia of chronic disease have low hematocrit leading to a reduced oxygen carrying capacity.  In anemia of chronic disease, the kidney produces less erythropoietin which leads to a normocytic anemia. Anemia results in reduced O2 carrying capacity and can lead to symptoms like headache, easy fatigability and shortness of breath. In anemic states, the dissolved O2 (Pa02) and oxygen saturation (SaO2) typically remain normal. Remember that the total oxygen content of blood is a function of the hemoglobin concentration, the oxygen saturation of hemoglobin, and the partial pressure of oxygen dissolved in the blood, though the latter plays an insignificant role in most instances (exception would be CO poisoning).

questions.text: A 49-year-old obese man presents to the emergency department with a fever and a cough productive of bloody sputum. He has also been waking up at night frequently, which he attributes to sweating while asleep. He is also proud of recently losing some weight but denies actively trying to do so. He is started on a course of therapy and leaves against medical advice before his physician is able to explain the medications. He returns two days later because he is concerned that his eyes are bleeding. The area of the lung most likely affected by this patient's condition has which of the following characteristics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This patient with productive blood cough, weight loss, fever, and night sweats most likely has tuberculosis, which grows in the apex of the lung because it has low perfusion, low ventilation, and a resulting high V/Q ratio.  Ventilation and perfusion are not distributed evenly throughout the lung. Perfusion is greater in the base of the lung than in the apex due to gravity. Ventilation is also greater in the base of the lung than in the apex due to greater relative expansion of the alveoli upon inhalation. The decrease in perfusion at the apex of the lung is much greater than the decrease in ventilation so the ventilation to perfusion (V/Q) ratio at the apex is high. This increase in V/Q ratio makes the apex more oxygen rich and more attractive for aerobic bacteria such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: 35-year-old man has a vital capacity (VC) of 5 L, a tidal volume (TV) of 0.5 L, an inspiratory capacity of 3.5 L, and a functional residual capacity (FRC) of 2.5 L. What is his expiratory reserve volume (ERV)?

questions.text: On the accompanying graph, the shift from curve A to curve B could be caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Because fetal hemoglobin (HbF) has a greater affinity for O2 than does adult hemoglobin, the O2–hemoglobin dissociation curve would shift to the left. Carbon monoxide poisoning would cause a shift to the left, but would also cause a decrease in total O2-carrying capacity (decreased percent saturation) because CO occupies O2-binding sites. Decreased pH, increased temperature, and increased 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (DPG) all would shift the curve to the right.

questions.text: The shift from curve A to curve B is associated with-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A shift to the left of the O2–hemoglobin dissociation curve represents an increased affinity of hemoglobin for O2. Accordingly, at any given level of PO2, the percent saturation is increased, the P50 is decreased (read the PO2 at 50% saturation), and the ability to unload O2 to the tissues is impaired (because of the higher affinity of hemoglobin for O2). The O2-carrying capacity is determined by haemoglobin concentration and is unaffected by the shift from curve A to curve B.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is watching a nail-biting finish of a crucial one-day cricket match. His sympathetic discharge increases to maximal values. Which set of changes would be expected in response to this increased sympathetic output?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Increased mean systemic filling pressure, increased resistance to venous return, increased venous return.
 Increased sympathetic discharge causes a venoconstriction, increases venous tone and mean systemic filling pressure (Psf). It will also cause an increase in resistance to venous return (RVR). 

VR = (Psf – RAP)/ RVR. With increased sympathetic discharge there is increase in both Psf and RVR but
because the relative increase in Psf is more than the increase in RVR, there is increase in VR.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male severs his brachial artery in a motorcycle accident. A bystander applies a tourniquet on the upper arm to stop the bleeding. He is taken to the Emergency of a nearby hospital. On arrival the man is only slightly hypotensive and his pupils are normal and reactive. The greatest percentage of the redistributed blood comes from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Venules and veins 

Venules, veins, and vena cava are capacitance vessels. Almost two-thirds of the blood volume is present on the venous side of the circulation. Increase in sympathetic discharge causes a venoconstriction, which in turn decreases the venous capacitance and shifts the blood from the venous to the arterial circulation.

Blowing murmurs of relatively high pitch are usually murmurs associated with valvular insufficiency. Patients with AR typically have widened pulse pressures. In this case the pulse pressure is 100 mm Hg.

questions.text: A patient with type I diabetes is not on insulin therapy has a fasting blood glucose of 400mg/dL. What would be the respiratory quotient likely be in this patient after eating a light meal containing 60% carbohydrates, 20% proteins and 20% fats?

questions.text: An apparently healthy 15-year-old boy dies during a minor surgical procedure while under general anesthesia. The boy’s grandfather has also died during a surgical procedure. A clinical assessment team determines that the child had malignant hyperthermia (MH). MH is an inherited disease in which the triggering agents, such as certain anesthetics, stimulate calcium release from storage sites in muscle, leading to elevated concentration of sarcoplasmic calcium. The MH crisis is most likely to be associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Defective ryanodine receptors

In malignant hyperthermia, defective ryanodine receptors respond to anesthetics such as, halothane, ether, etc., by opening the calcium channels on the sarcoplasmic reticulum causing uncontrolled release of calcium and thus, increasing the sarcoplasmic calcium. This increase in sarcoplasmic calcium results in continuous contraction of the muscles. This in turn results in increase in body temperature, increased anerobic metabolism, increased CO2 production, and increased lactic acid production. 

Calsequestrin is a calcium binding protein present in sarcoplasmic reticulum of muscle fibres and is not affected by halothane or halogenated anesthetics. 

DHPR present on the T-tubule membrane are voltage sensors and are activated by the skeletal muscle fibre action potential and are not affected by halogenated anesthetics.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for elasticity in skeletal muscle?

questions.text: A 65- year-old man presented with progressive leg weakness and a diagnosis of LEMS (Lambert- Eaton myasthenic syndrome) was made by serial repetitive nerve stimulation test. Which of the following channels are affected in Lamber-Eaton syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Voltage- gated calcium channels on pre- synaptic membrane

  • LEMS is caused by an auto-immune attach against voltage-gated calcium channels on the pre-synaptic membrane at the NMJ.
  • It is usually adult- onset and has a similar occurrence in males and females. Proximal muscles of the lower extremities are primarily affected, producing a waddling gait and difficulty in raising arms.
  • Repetitive stimulation of the motor nerve facilitates accumulation of calcium in the nerve terminal and increases acetylcholine release, leading to increase in muscle strength. This is in contrast to myasthenia gravis in which symptoms are exacerbated by repetitive stimulation.
  • About 40% of the patients of LEMS also have cancer, especially small cell cancer of the lung.
  • Patients of LEMS may also have lymphosarcoma, malignant thymoma, cancer of the breast, stomach, colon, prostate, bladder, kidney, or gallbladder.
