questions.text: Which of the following best describes a motor unit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Single muscle fibre and all the Aα motor neurons supplying it

Single A alpha motor neuron and all the muscle fibres it innervates constitute a motor unit. The number of muscle fibres in each motor unit varies. In muscles concerned with fine, graded and precise movements, such as those of the hand and those concerned with movements of the eyeball, each motor unit innervates very few (3- 6) muscle fibres. On the other hand, calf muscles may have up to 600 muscle fibres in each motor unit.

questions.text:
Given below is a graph of the length-tension relationship. Which of the following are true regarding optimum length? (multiple correct options).

A. Optimum length corresponds to a sarcomere length of 2- 2.2 microns

B. There are maximum number of actin- myosin cross bridges at optimum length

C. There is minimum overlap between actin and myosin

D. Optimum length is also known as the resting length

At optimum length, active and passive tension are maximum.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A, B, D are correct. At optimum length, total tension, active tension and passive tension are maximum. Optimum length corresponds to a sarcomere length of 2- 2.2 microns. There is maximum overlap between actin and myosin with maximum number of actin- myosin cross bridges at this length. Optimum length is also known as the resting length.

choices.text: Acts on SFO and OVLT to cause a dipsogenic effect
Acts on area postrema and increases the sensitivity of the baroreceptor reflex

questions.text: All of the following are true about angiotensin II except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Angiotensin II acts on area postrema, decreases the sensitivity of the baroreceptors and thus, potentiates the pressor effect of angiotensin II.

questions.text: Shown below is an electron microscopic picture of a sarcomere. Which of the following represent the H-zone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A is the dark or A (anisotropic to light) band which consists of myosin and overlapped actin. Within the A-band there is lighter area called the H-zone (D), which consists of only myosin. 
E is the I (isotropic to light) or light band- it consists of only actin

questions.text: Which of the following is greater in after loaded muscle contractions as compared to preloaded muscle contractions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Latent period.

•    Preload is the load placed on a muscle before the muscle contracts. 

•    It serves to stretch the muscle sarcomeres, thus producing a passive tension across the muscle.

•    This passive tension increases muscle contraction in two ways:

    (i) It adds an elastic recoil force to the muscle during its contraction;

    (ii) It stretches the muscle to its resting length, producing the optimum     length-tension relationship for active force generation. 

•    In real life situations, it is a common practice to pre-stretch a muscle using antagonist muscles. 

•    After load is an opposing force which the muscle encounters immediately after it starts contracting. It is a force that a muscle must overcome before an observable shortening of the muscle can occur.

•    The contraction and work done of an after-loaded muscle is comparatively lesser.

choices.text: Depletion of voltage-gated calcium channels in certain motor neurons
Development of macro motor units after recovery from poliomyelitis
Over exertion resulting in junction fatigue

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman visits her physician because of double vision, drooping of eyelids, difficulty in chewing and swallowing, and general weakness in her limbs. All these symptoms worsen with exercise and occur more frequently late in the day. The physician suspects myasthenia gravis and orders a Tensilon test. The test is positive. What is the most likely basis for the symptoms described in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies

Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a chronic autoimmune disorder in which antibodies destroy the acetylcholine receptors on the motor end plate, resulting in weakness of the skeletal muscles. Myasthenia gravis affects the voluntary muscles of the body, especially those that control the eyes, mouth, throat and limbs.

Tensilon (Edrophonium) is a drug that blocks the breakdown of acetylcholine, helping the neurotransmitter acetylcholine activate the muscle. For patients who do not have MG, the drug will do nothing to improve tired muscles. However, for patients with MG, the test is said to be positive when muscle strength improves.

choices.text: Excessive eating, rage and aggression, hyperactivity

questions.text: Bilateral lesions involving the lateral hypothalamus will lead to which of the following deficits?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Decreased eating and drinking

Lateral hypothalamus is the hunger, thirst, reward and pleasure center. Lesion of this area will lead to decreased eating and drinking. 

Lesions involving the ventromedial hypothalamus lead to excessive eating (hyperphagia), excessive drinking, rage and aggression, and hyperactivity.

questions.text: Which of the following structures of the cerebellum has a topographical representation of the body?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Medial and intermediate lobes 

The medial and intermediate lobes of the cerebellum have a distinct topographical representation of the body. These areas are responsible for coordinating the contraction of the muscles of the body for intended motion.

questions.text: Gibbs- Donnan equilibrium is based on which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Intracellular proteins Donnan and Gibbs showed that in the presence of a non-diffusible ion (proteins), the diffusible ions distribute themselves so that equilibrium, their concentration ratios are equal:

This is the Gibbs- Donnan equation. It is applicable for any pair of cations and anions of the same valence.

choices.text: Decrease in the number of individual muscle fibres in the left gastrocnemius
Decrease in blood flow to the muscle caused by constriction from the cast
Temporary reduction in actin and myosin protein synthesis
Increase in glycolytic activity in the affected muscle

questions.text: A 18- year old football player sustained a left tibial fracture. The left lower leg was placed in a cast for 8 weeks. After the cast was removed the left gastrocnemius muscle was found to be significantly smaller in circumference than the right. What is the most likely explanation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Temporary reduction in actin and myosin protein synthesis

Skeletal muscle continuously remodels in response to their level of use. When a muscle is inactive for an extended period, the rate of synthesis of contractile proteins in individual muscle fibres decreases resulting in overall reduction in muscle mass. This reversible reduction in muscle mass is called atrophy.

questions.text: A 70-year old man has congestive cardiac failure. His cardiac output is 4L/min, bp is 110/80 mm Hg and heart rate is 90/minute. Further tests reveal that his right atrial pressure is 10 mm Hg. Which of the following will be expected to increase in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Increase in RAP to 10 mm Hg decreases the venous return to the heart and therefore, increase the vena cava hydrostatic pressure. This in turn increases the tissue capillary hydrostatic pressure, especially in the capillaries of the lower limb (if patient is ambulant), leading to pedal edema.

questions.text: The equation which is used to calculate the magnitude of the equilibrium potential of a freely diffusible ion is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Donnan and Gibbs showed that in the presence of a non diffusible ion, the diffusible ions distribute themselves so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal. This is the Gibbs Donnan Equation.

If a membrane is freely permeable to an ion, magnitude of potential difference for that ion at equilibrium (equilibrium potential or Nernst potential) can be calcuklated by the Nernst Equation. 
Goldmann Hodgkin Katz equation is used to calculate the RMP.

Henderson Hasselbach equation is used to calculate the pH of a buffer solution containing given concentrations of an acid and its conjugate base.

choices.text: Fast-twitch muscle fibres are more dependent on the phosphagen and glycogen- lactic acid systems
Fast-twitch muscle fibres have more myoglobin
Fewer capillaries surround slow-twitch muscle fibres
Fast twitch muscle fibres are smaller in diameter

questions.text: Which of the following statements comparing fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscle fibres is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fast-twitch muscle fibres are more dependent on the phosphagen and glycogen- lactic acid systems

Fast twitch muscle fibres are more dependent on anaerobic metabolism whereas slow-twitch muscle fibres are more dependent on aerobic metabolism.

Slow-twitch muscle fibres have more mitochondria, more myoglobin and a higher capillary density. 

Fast-twitch muscle fibres tend to be larger in diameter as compared to small-twitch muscle fibres.

questions.text: Most of the energy for strenuous exercise that lasts for more than 5- 10 seconds but less than 1 to 2 minutes comes from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anaerobic glycolysis

ATP stores and ATP from phosphocreatine can sustain exercise for another the first 5- 10 seconds only. Energy for strenuous exercise for more than 5- 10 seconds but less than 1-2 minutes is derived from anaerobic glycolysis. Release of energy by glycolysis occurs much more rapidly than oxidative release of energy, which is much too slow to supply the needs of the muscle in the first few minutes of exercise

questions.text:
The following events occur at an excitatory synapse. 

a.	Ligand- gated channels open in the post synaptic membrane to allow influx of sodium

b.	Synaptic vesicles bind to pre-synaptic membrane

c.	Depolarization of pre-synaptic membrane

d.	Opening of calcium channels cause influx of calcium 

Which of the following is the correct sequence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

c, d, b, a

Arrival of the action potential at the pre-synaptic membrane, causes opening of calcium channels. This is followed by calcium influx. Vesicles in the pre-synaptic axon terminal bind to the presynaptic membrane. This is followed by exocytosis of the neurotransmitter. The neurotransmitter binds to its receptors on the post synaptic membrane leading to electrical changes in the post- synaptic neuron.

questions.text: If alveolar surface area is decreased by 50% and pulmonary fibrosis leads to doubling of diffusion distance, how will the diffusion of O2 be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Decreases by 75%

Diffusion of gases across the respiratory membrane follows the Fick’s law of diffusion. 
Net transport 

= - (diffusion coefficient) (surface area) (concentration gradient)/ (thickness of membrane)

Transport is directly proportional to surface area and inverse to the thickness of membrane. If the surface area is decreased to half and thickness of membrane is doubled, transport is decreases to one-fourth or in other words, decreases by 75%.

choices.text: Can be blocked by specific transporters

questions.text: Simple diffusion and facilitated diffusion share which of the following characteristics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Simple diffusion and facilitated diffusion are examples of passive transport and therefore, do not require energy for transport.

questions.text: Most important buffer in the interstitial fluid is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bicarbonate

The principal buffer in the interstitial fluid is bicarbonate.

questions.text: Hypertonic 5% saline contains how much of Na+ in meq/l?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

854

1 equivalent of a substance = 1 mole of that substance/ (No. of metal ions) X (valence)
For NaCl, 1 equivalent = 1 mole 

5% NaCl = 5 gm of NaCl in 100mL = 50 gm of NaCl in 1000mL

58.5	gm of NaCl = 1 mole of NaCl

50 gm of NaCl = 50/58.5 mole = 0.854 mole = 854 millimole = 854 milliequivalent.

choices.text: ESV first decreases and then increases

questions.text: During exercise in physiological limits what is the effect on end systolic volume?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

During exercise increased sympathetic discharge increases force of contraction of the heart resulting in a better emptying of the ventricles and a decreased end systolic volume.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for Bezold Jarish Reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Capsaicin 		

Ref: Ganong, 25thed/p. 592, 662

BEZOLD-JARISCH REFLEX

•	Intracardiac injections of chemicals like serotonin, veratridine, capsaicin, phenyldiguanide activates this reflex

•	Afferents for this reflex travel through unmyelinated vagal C fiber endings

•	The reflex responses are:

	Apnea followed by rapid breathing

	Hypotension

	Bradycardia

•	Clinical importance of Bezold-Jarisch reflex

	This reflex is responsible for sinus bradycardia seen during myocardial infarction

	This reflex is one of the cause for profound bradycardia and circulatory collapse after spinal anesthesia

choices.text: Gap junctions form a cytoplasmic “tunnel” for diffusion of small molecules (<1000 Da) between two neighbouring cells
Gap junctions are formed by proteins called connexons
Connexons in the membrane of one cell are lined up with connexons of a neighbouring cell to form dodecameric gap junctions

questions.text: All of the following are true about gap junctions except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Gap junctions form chemical synapses

Gap junctions form electrical synapses. They for a low resistance path for bi-directional movement of ions, molecules, sugars and amino acids less than 1000 Daltons.

choices.text: Decreased renal blood flow, decreased glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure
Increased renal blood flow, increased glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure
Decreased renal blood flow, increased glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure
Increased renal blood flow, decreased glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: Which changes would you expect to find after administration of a vasodilator drug that caused a 50% decrease in afferent arteriolar resistance and no change in arterial pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increased renal blood flow, Increased glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure

A reduction in the renal afferent arteriolar resistance will increase the renal blood flow. More the flow into the glomerular capillaries, more will be the glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure.

questions.text: The GFR of a 50-year-old man decreases by 50% and remains at that level. Plasma concentration of which of the following substances will be increased to the greatest extent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Creatinine

Creatinine is freely filtered, not reabsorbed and slightly secreted. Excretion of creatinine is, therefore, dependent almost entirely on glomerular filtration. A decrease in GFR will therefore, cause the greatest increase in plasma concentration of creatinine.  

Plasma concentrations of glucose, potassium and sodium are closely regulated by multiple mechanisms that keep them relatively constant even when the GFR falls to very low levels.

questions.text: All of the following are present on the alpha subunit of the sodium potassium ATPase pump except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

glycosylation site

Glycosylation site is on the beta subunit.

choices.text: Includes phagocytosis and pinocytosis, but not clathrin- mediated or caveolae dependent uptake of extracellular contents
Refers to merging of an intracellular vesicle with the plasma membrane to deliver vesicular contents to the ECF
Refers to the invagination of the cell membrane to uptake extracellular contents into the cell
Refers vesicular trafficking between golgi apparatus

questions.text: Which of the following is true about endocytosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Refers to the invagination of the cell membrane to uptake extracellular contents into the cell. It includes phagocytosis (“cell eating”) and pinocytosis (“cell drinking”), clathrin- mediated endocytosis and caveolae dependent uptake of extracellular contents.

questions.text: Sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

NIS (secondary active co-transport) is present in

•	Thyroid cells

•	Salivary glands

•	Stomach

•	Intestinal epithelial cells (apical membrane)

•	Gestational breast

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms for transport across the luminal cell membrane of an enterocyte is present in newborns and infants but not in adults?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Intestinal absorption of immunoglobulins (in colostrum) during early infancy occurs by endocytosis. This ability to absorb large molecules by endocytosis occurs during the first several months of life but is lost thereafter. Simple diffusion, facilitated diffusion, primary and secondary active transports are all normal processes in enterocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following ions is higher in the ICF?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 K+

questions.text: Which of the following aquaporin is involved in water reabsorption from the PCT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aquaporin 1 is present on both the apical and basolateral membrane of the cells of the PCT. Water reabsorption in the PCT is solute driven and follows the osmotic gradient set up by the active transport of solutes, and isotonicity is maintained.

questions.text: If an artery is partially occluded by an embolus such that its radius becomes one- half the pre-occlusion value, which of the following parameters will decrease by a factor of 16?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Blood flow is directly proportional to the fourth power of radius. Decrease in radius to half reduces the flow to 1/16th of its pre occlusion value.

choices.text: Negative feedback system with error of zero
Negative feedback system with correction of zero
Negative feedback system with gain of zero
There is no such thing as infinite gain in a feedback system

questions.text: Which of the following describes infinite feedback gain principle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Negative feedback system with error of zero

For a negative feedback system,

Gain = correction/ error

If error is zero, the gain is infinite.

The control of arterial pressure by the renal- body fluid mechanism, where the arterial pressure always 
exactly comes back to equilibrium point, makes it an example of infinite feedback gain principle.

questions.text: The most important factor which determines the movement of a permeant substance across the cell membrane is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Diffusion coefficient of a substance is determined mainly by the lipid solubility of that substance.

questions.text: In an ideal solution, which of the following is correct? (P is osmotic pressure, n is number of particles, R is gas constant, T is absolute temperature, V is volume)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

P = nRT/V. If T is constant, osmotic pressure is proportional to the number of particles in solution per unit volume of the solution.

questions.text: Increase in which of the following ion in the ECF has the maximum effect on neuronal excitability?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation- with increase in K+ concentration in ECF, the gradient for potassium will decrease. This causes less K+ to diffuse out from the cell. Increase in positive charge inside the cells causes the membrane potential to become less negative resulting in depolarization and increase in excitability. One of the common symptoms of hyperkalemia is arrythmias.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is taken to a physician because of sore throat. An antibiotic is prescribed that can enter most body tissues but cannot penetrate the blood brain barrier. The blood brain barrier can be attributed primarily to which cell type?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Endothelial cells 

Tight junctions between the endothelial cells are responsible for the blood brain barrier. Astrocytes induce the formation of tight junctions.

choices.text: Inability to discretely localize touch sensation over the opposite face and upper limb
Inability to judge the weight of easily recognizable objects
Inability to accurately assess the texture of common objects by touching them with the fingers
Inability to move the contralateral arm and leg

questions.text: Which somatosensory deficit is NOT typically seen after the development of lesions that involve the post central gyrus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Inability to move the contralateral arm and leg 

Inability to move the contralateral arm and leg is a motor deficit and will not be typically seen after damage to the primary somatosensory cortex.

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravida has a normal vaginal delivery. The infant is phenotypically male but has hypospadias and a small phallus. The testes are well developed but reside in the inguinal area. His physical examination, including the bp, is otherwise normal. Serum testosterone is within normal limits. A karyotype is performed and shows 46, XY. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

5α-reductase 

5α-reductase converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. In a male fetus with congenital deficiency of 5α-reductase, the internal genitalia develop normally due to the presence of testosterone, but the external genitalia do not develop properly due to lack of DHT, resulting in male pseudohermaphrodites. The genitalia at birth can range from a small phallus with hypospadias to ambiguous or female-type genitalia.

questions.text: Which change would you expect in a patient consuming a high sodium diet (200mEq/day) compared with the same patient on a normal sodium diet (100mEq/day), assuming steady-state conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Decreased renin activity 

Sodium and, therefore, water retention increases the ECF volume decreasing renin secretion. Decreased renin will decrease aldosterone secretion. Reduction in aldosterone will reduce potassium secretion in the collecting tubules. 

Increase in ECF volume increases ANP and decreases ADH secretion.

questions.text: A clinical experiment is conducted in which one group is given 50gms of glucose i/v and another group is given 50gms of glucose orally. Which of the following can explain why the oral glucose load is cleared from the blood at a faster rate compared with the i/v glucose load?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

GLP- induced insulin release 

GLP-1 secreted by the L cells is k/a physiologic beta cell stimulating hormone of GI tract. It stimulates the release of Insulin by beta cells of pancreas. This effect will not be seen after i/v glucose.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with complaints of increasing fatigue and weight gain. She also complains of dry skin. Her hair has also been thinning. Laboratory evaluation shows high serum TSH, low T3 and T4 levels. She is advised T3 supplementation. After administering T3 which of the following hormone level changes are most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Decrease in TSH 

The patient has primary hypothyroidism with low T3 and T4 and elevated TSH. Exogenous T3 supplementation rapidly suppresses TSH levels by negative feedback which in turn decreases T4 secretion from the thyroid gland. Furthermore, RT3 also decreases because less T4 is available for conversion.

questions.text:
Given below are four statements regarding airway resistance of which one or more may be correct. Choose the correct option using the following key.

1. Airway resistance is low in large as well as in small diameter airways

2. Airway resistance is highest in medium sized airways

3. Medium sized airways have a turbulent airflow which increases the resistance to airflow

4. Density of the gas can also affect airway resistance
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ref– Read the text below

Sol:

Airway resistance is low in large as well as in small diameter airways but highest in medium sized airways. Medium sized airways have a turbulent airflow which increases the resistance to airflow. Density of the gas can also affect airway resistance.

questions.text: In an animal experiment the levels of various endogenous compounds are measured in the spinal fluid after application of painful stimuli. One of the compounds that increases because of this experiment is a pentapeptide with a high affinity for delta and mu-receptors. Which of the following substance is most likely to have a common molecular origin with the pentapeptide described above?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ACTH

ACTH is synthesized as a large precursor molecule- POMC or pro opio melanocortin, which is cleaved to form a family of hormones. POMC is hydrolysed to- 

•	ACTH

•	β-lipotropin

•	β-endorphin

β-endorphin is an opioid peptide that has five amino acid residues (pentapeptide) of met-enkephalin at its amino terminal end.

questions.text:
A patient is being evaluated for hypoventilation. He is asked to take several deep breaths in rapid succession, and the following information is obtained:

Which of the following is the most likely site of this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Neuromuscular junction

With each deep breath electrical activity in the phrenic nerve and pleural pressure changes are recorded. Even though the electrical activity in the phrenic nerve is normal the pleural pressure changes reduce with each breath, indicating gradual weakening of the diaphragm. This most likely site of the patient’s disease is neuromuscular junction. 

If the site of the disease were either the brain stem of peripheral nerve the electrical activity in the phrenic nerve would have been affected. 

If the site of the disease were the cortex, the patient would not have been able to take deep breaths voluntarily.

questions.text: Which point in the figure given below corresponds with arterial blood in a severely anemic patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Point D

In a severely anemic patient there is a decrease in the O2 content of the blood. The O2 saturation of Hb in the arterial blood and the PO2 are not affected.

questions.text: The figure given below shows three different compliance curves- S, T, U for isolated lungs subjected to various transpulmonary pressures. Which of the following best describes the relative compliance for the three lungs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

S > T > U

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in transpulmonary pressure. More the slope, more is the compliance. Compliance of lung S is more than that of T which is more than U.

questions.text: Which of the following is due to the axon reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Flare

When the skin is stroked firmly with appointed instrument, the triple response (also k/a Lewis’ triple response), which is a normal response to injury, is seen.  It consists of the following:-

a.	Red reaction (k/a red dermographism)- there is reddening at the site which appears in about 10 seconds. This initial redness is due to capillary dilatation, a direct response of the capillaries to pressure. 

b.	Flare- this is a spreading redness from the site of injury due to arteriolar dilatation. This is due to the “axon reflex”, a response in which impulses initiated in sensory nerves by the injury are relayed antidromically down other branches of the sensory nerve fibers. The transmitter released at the central termination of the sensory C fiber neurons is substance P. Substance P and CGRP are present in all parts of neurons. Both dilate arterioles and, in addition, substance P causes extravasation of fluid. 
The axon reflex persists after total sympathectomy. Flare is absent in locally anesthetized skin and in denervated skin after the sensory nerves have degenerated, but is present after a nerve block or section above the site of injury. This indicates that flare is due to the axon reflex, a neural response. 

c.	Wheal- swelling or local edema is due to increased permeability of the capillaries and post capillary 
venules, with consequent extravasation of fluid. Extravasation is believed to be due to release of substance P. Effective peptide antagonists to substance P have been developed, and they reduce the extravasation.

questions.text: The double Bohr’s effect is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Placental circulation

The “double bohr’s effect” helps to increase fetal oxygenation. The transfer of carbon dioxide from the fetal to the maternal blood shifts the maternal OHDC to the right and fetal curve to the left, facilitating the transfer of oxygen across the placenta from mother to the fetus.

questions.text: The receptors responsible for rapid, shallow breathing are-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 J receptors

J or juxtacapillary receptors located at the alveolo capillary junction are stimulated by 

•	Pulmonary congestion

•	Pulmonary edema

•	Pulmonary embolism

Stimulation of the J receptors results in 

•	Apnea followed by rapid, shallow ventilation

•	Hypotension

•	Bradycardia

Pulmonary stretch receptors are responsible for Hering Breur Reflex.

Chemoreceptor stimulation causes increase in rate and depth of ventilation.

Receptors for tidal respiration are muscle spindles in the diaphragm and intercostal muscles.

questions.text: Maximum velocity of blood flow is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aorta

Aorta has the least cross-sectional area. Therefore, the maximum velocity of flow is in the aorta

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is k/a “hydrocholeretic”?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Secretin

Secretin increases the bicarbonate and therefore, water content of bile. Hence it is k/a hydrocholeretic.

questions.text: Assume you have a patient who need fluid therapy and you decide to administer 2L of 0.45% NaCl solution intravenously. After osmotic equilibrium, which of the following will NOT be expected compared with before the infusion of the NaCl?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increase in intracellular osmolality 

Infusion of hypotonic fluid results in increase in TBW, increase in ICF and ECF volume but a decrease in ICF and ECF osmolality.

questions.text: A new seizure drug is being investigated that binds to and activates GABA-A receptors in the CNS. During their experiments, a researcher uses a micro electrode to measure the RMP of a neuron. He records RMP of -70mV. Which of the following membrane potentials is likely to be recorded following exposure to the drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

-75mV

GABA-A receptors are ionotropic receptors which cause opening of chloride channels, leading to hyperpolarization of the cell. GABA-A agonist will, therefore, cause the RMP of the cell to become more negative or -75mV.

questions.text: Which of the following GI secretions has the highest pH?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Brunner’s gland secretion

Saliva has a pH of 6.0 to 8.0 (usually 7.0 to 8.0).

Intestinal secretion or Succus entericus has a pH of 7.0 to 8.0.

Pancreatic secretions have a pH of up to 8.8.

Brunners’ gland secretion has a pH of up to 9.3.

questions.text: The receptors for the Hering- Breur reflex are located in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bronchi and bronchioles

The receptors for the Hering Breur reflex are located in the tracheobronchial tree. They respond to increased stretch to limit inspiration.

questions.text: Neurons located in which of the following release serotonin as their neurotransmitter?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Raphe magnus nucleus

Raphe magnus nucleus located in the pons secrete serotonin. 

Locus ceruleus- nor epinephrine.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in hyperbaric oxygen therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased arterial PCO2

Hyperbaric oxygen works by increasing the DISSOLVED component of oxygen in the blood. The result will be 

•	Increased arterial PO2

•	Increased oxygen content in blood

•	Increased tissue PO2

•	No change in arterial pH or CO2

Indications for hyperbaric oxygen are:_

•	Air embolism

•	Decompression sickness

•	CO poisoning

•	Burns

•	Crush injuries

•	Compromised skin flaps

•	Radiation necrosis

•	Necrotizing infections

•	Gas gangrene

•	Intracranial abscess

questions.text: Which of the following will cause a decrease in plasma potassium levels by causing a shift in potassium from ECF to ICF?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Insulin excess

Insulin causes a shift of potassium from ECF to ICF causing a decrease in plasma potassium levels.

questions.text: Which of the following water-soluble hormones does not need a second messenger?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Insulin

Insulin does not need a second messenger because the insulin receptor itself has tyrosine kinase activity. 
DAG is the second messenger for Growth hormone and cAMP for ADH and Glucagon.

questions.text: Changes in which of the following does not affect respiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Arterial Na+ concentration

Changes in arterial Na+ concentration has no effect on respiration. Increase in arterial H+ and PCO2 will stimulate the chemoreceptors producing an increase in rate and depth of ventilation. Increase in arterial HCO3- concentration (alkalosis) tends to suppress the respiratory drive.

questions.text: PO2 of 8kPa corresponds with Hb saturation of -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

90%

PO2 of 8kPa or 60mm Hg (1kPa = 7.5mm Hg) corresponds to a Hb saturation of 89%. 90% is, therefore, the best answer.

choices.text: Shift of OHDC to the right
Decrease in the number of mitochondria

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen during acclimatization to high altitude?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Decrease in the number of mitochondria

Acclimatization to high altitude is due to the operation of a number of compensatory mechanisms. These include:-

•	Increased urinary excretion of bicarbonates. High altitude results in hypoxic hypoxia stimulating the peripheral chemoreceptors. The resulting hyperventilation results in respiratory alkalosis. Alkalosis suppresses the chemoreceptor response. Kidneys increase the urinary excretion of bicarbonates reducing the pH that increases the response to hypoxia. 

•	Shift of OHDC to the right- respiratory alkalosis at hugh altitude causes a shift of the OHDC to the left, but a concomitant increase in red blood cell 2,3- DPG shifts the OHDC to the right. The net effect is shift to right and a small increase in P50.

•	Increased secretion of erythropoietin- hypoxia is potent stimulus for secretion of EPO from the kidneys. 

•	Hypoxia causes increase in the number of mitochondria, which are the site of oxidative reactions. Myoglobin also increases which facilitates the movement of O2 to the tissues, the tissue content of cytochrome enzymes also increases.

questions.text: Migrating motor complex is triggered by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Motilin

MMCs, which occur in the inter digestive period, are triggered by Motilin secreted by M cells in the small intestine.

questions.text: Maximum CO2 transport in venous blood occurs as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

As bicarbonates

70% of the CO2 in venous blood is in the form of bicarbonates. 

CO2 reacts with amine radicals of hemoglobin to form carbamino compounds. 

The solubility of CO2 is 0.067mL/ 100 mL/ mm Hg. Venous PCO2 is 45 mm Hg. At this PCO2 the amount of dissolved CO2 in plasma is 2.7mL/100mL of blood. Arterial blood has a PCO2 is 40 mm Hg and the amount of dissolved CO2 is 2.4mL/100mL of blood. This gives a difference of only about 0.3mL/100mL of dissolved CO2 in venous and arterial blood. This is about 7% of all the CO2 normally transported.

choices.text: Decrease in bp from 120 mm Hg to 90 mm Hg

questions.text: Which of the following is likely to produce an increase in cerebral blood flow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Decrease in O2

The most potent stimulator for cerebral blood flow is increase in CO2 followed by decrease in O2 and increase in cerebral metabolic activity. 

Between a mean arterial pressure of 65- and 140-mm Hg, autoregulatory mechanisms maintain a constant cerebral blood flow. So, a change in bp from 120 to 90 mm Hg will not produce any change in blood flow.

questions.text: Which of the following stimulator- mediator pair inhibits gastrin secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Acid- Somatostatin

Acid directly acts on delta cells in the small intestine to stimulate release of somatostatin. Somatostatin decreases acid secretion by acting directly on parietal cells decreasing the output of acid and indirectly by inhibiting gastrin secretion from G cells in the antrum. 
Acid is a weak stimulus for CCK release but CCK does not inhibit or stimulate gastrin secretion. 
Acid does not increase secretion of GLP-1 or Motilin.

questions.text: Which anterior pituitary hormone plays a major role in the regulation of a nonendocrine target gland?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Prolactin

The major target tissue for prolactin is the breast where it stimulates the secretion of milk. The other anterior pituitary hormones (ACTH, TSH, FSH) stimulate other endocrine glands.

choices.text: The neonate experienced malnutrition in utero
The mother was malnourished during her pregnancy
The mother is diabetic, with poorly controlled hyperglycemia

questions.text: At birth, a large, well-nourished baby is found to have a plasma glucose of 17mg/dL and a plasma insulin concentration twice the normal value. What is the explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The mother is diabetic, with poorly controlled hyperglycemia

An infant born to a diabetic mother with poorly controlled hyperglycemia will have hyperglycemia and therefore, hyperinsulinemia in utero. The infant’s blood glucose may fall to less than 20mg/dL shortly after birth.

questions.text: Cortisone is administered to a 30-year-old woman for the treatment of an auto-immune disease. Which of the following is most likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased insulin secretion

Steroids tend to increase blood glucose concentration. As a result insulin secretion is increased

choices.text: Phosphate reabsorptive pathways in the renal tubules

questions.text: The function of which of the following is increased by an elevated parathormone concentration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Osteoclasts

PTH receptors are on osteoblasts but it causes a secondary increase in osteoclastic activity increasing bone resorption.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to her physician with an enlarged thyroid gland and high plasma levels of T4 and T3. Which of the following is likely to be decreased?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Peripheral resistance

Thyroid hormones increase the metabolic rate in tissues and therefore, vasodilation, increasing blood flow and therefore, cardiac output.

questions.text: Which structure serves as an “alternate pathway” for signals from the motor cortex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Red nucleus

Motor cortex sends fibres to the red nucleus in the midbrain which in turn gives rise to the rubrospinal tract. The rubrospinal tract is the “alternate motor pathway”.

questions.text: Shown in the graph given below is the time taken by four receptors for adaptation. Which line represents the Pacinian corpuscles?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Line D

Pacinian corpuscle is a very rapidly adapting touch receptor. The impulses generated per second in the receptor represented by line D very rapidly touch the baseline, indicating that this is a very rapidly adapting receptor.

choices.text: Inappropriately high secretion rate of ACTH

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman has osteoporosis, hypertension, hirsuitism, and hyperpigmentation. Magnetic resonance imaging indicates that the pituitary gland is not enlarged. Which condition is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Osteoporosis, hypertension, hirsuitism, and hyperpigmentation are all symptoms of Cushing’s syndrome associated with high ACTH. Normal size pituitary gland indicates that the abnormally high ACTH is secreted from an ectopic tumor.

questions.text: A heroin addict has chronically increased levels of TBG. This would result in which of the following in this individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

No change in metabolic rate

With chronically elevated levels of TBG, there is increase in total and bound T4 but free T4 is normal.

questions.text: An input neuron to a diverging circuit causes the membrane potential to change from -65mV to -55mV. Which of the following best describes this change in potential?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Excitatory post synaptic potential = +10mV

The potential in the post synaptic neuron becomes less negative- this is k/a EPSP. EPSPs are always positive. IPSPs are negative.

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to an abnormality in the pituitary
Hyperthyroidism due to an abnormality in the hypothalamus
Hypothyroidism due to abnormality in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to abnormality in the hypothalamus

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman has “puffy” skin and is lethargic. His plasma TSH concentration is low and increases markedly when given TRH. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hypothyroidism due to abnormality in the pituitary

Since the patient’s plasma TSH is low and increases after giving TRH, it indicates that the abnormality lies in the pituitary.

questions.text: Some cells secrete chemicals into the ECF that act on cells in the same tissue. Which of the following refers to this type of regulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Paracrine

Chemicals secreted into the ECF acting on the neighbouring cells is paracrine secretion.

questions.text: A young woman is given daily injections of a substance beginning on the 16th day of her normal menstrual cycle and continuing for 3 weeks. As long as the injections continue, she does not menstruate. The injected substance could be which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

HCG

HCG has the same stimulatory effect as LH on the corpus luteum. Administration of HCG causes the corpus luteum to secrete estrogen and progesterone, preventing the degradation of the endometrium and the onset of menstruation.

choices.text: Right dorsal horn of spinal cord at the level of entry
Left dorsal horn of spinal cord at level of entry

questions.text: For a sensory nerve fibre that is connected to the Meissner’s corpuscles located on the fingertips of the right hand, the synapse with the second order neuron in the corresponding sensory pathway is in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Right dorsal column nucleus

Meissner’s corpuscle detects fine, well localized touch, slow vibration, texture and topognosis. Sensory fibres from the Meissner’s corpuscles travel in the posterior columns. Fibres of the dorsal column synapse with the second order neurons in the same side dorsal column nucleus in the medulla.

questions.text: Which of the following substances causes relaxation of the LES and fundus of the stomach during swallowing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Nitric oxide

Relaxation of the LES and fundus of the stomach during swallowing is k/a receptive relaxation. It is mediated by afferent and efferent pathways in the vagus and the neurotransmitter involved is nitric oxide.

choices.text: Contraction of descending and sigmoid colon

questions.text: The spinal cord of a 60-year-old woman is severed in an automobile accident. She devises a method to distend the rectum to initiate the rectosphincteric reflex. Rectal distension DOES NOT cause which of the following responses in this woman?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Contraction of external anal sphincter

When feces enters the rectum, it initiates signals that spread through the myenteric plexus to initiate peristaltic waves in the descending colon, sigmoid colon and rectum all of which force the feces towards the anus. Internal anal sphincter relaxes allowing the feces to pass. In patients with transected spinal cords, the defecation reflex causes automatic emptying of the bowel because the external anal sphincter is under voluntary control.

questions.text: The lieum and distal jejunum of a 25-year-old man are ruptured in a road traffic accident. The entire ileum and a portion of the distal jejunum are resected. What is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Vitamin B12 deficiency

Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the distal ileum. Resection of the distal ileum will result in Vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A 45-year old man inspired as much air as possible and then expired with maximum effort until no more air could be expired. The flow rate during expiration were recorded as the flow- volume curve given below. What is the PEFR in this man (in L/min)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

400 L/min

The highest point of the flow- volume curve coincides with the peak expiratory flow rate. PEFR is effort dependent.

questions.text: Which of the following substance added to the perfusate of an isolated rabbit’s heart causes the heart to stop in systole?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Calcium

Calcium causes ‘calcium rigor’ and causes the heart to stop in systole.

questions.text: Which system transmits with the highest degree of temporal and spatial fidelity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dorsal column medial leminiscal system 

DCML system has a high degree of spatial orientation of the nerve fibres with respect to their origin. DCML system is involved in transmission of sensory information that requires a high degree of spatial and temporal fidelity.

questions.text: Sweat glands and piloerector muscles of hairy skin are innervated by which type of fibres?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cholinergic post ganglionic sympathetic

Sweat glands and piloerector muscles of hairy skin are innervated by cholinergic post ganglionic sympathetic.
